_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Fire Monitors, Fire Hydrants & Hoses, Portable Fire Extinguishers
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Yearly inspection and testing of relief valves plant wide.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

The Paradis Gas Processing Plant has implemented all the elements of a Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and all the elements of OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The plant has also implemented all the elements of Williams Midstream?s System Integrity Plan (SIP), which contains additional environmental, health and safety standards.

The Paradis Gas Processing Plant?s Emergency Response Plan is site-specific.  It includes actions by plant employees as well as required notification and coordination with local responders and agencies.  All employees are trained in the execution of the Emergency Response Plan and drills are conducted annually.

THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE:

The Paradis Gas Processing Plant is located near Paradis, Louisiana at 15849 Old Spanish Trail (LA HWY. 631).  The processes operated at the Paradis Gas Processing Plant include:  a natural gas liquid fractionating process; and product storage and shipping.  Product shipping is either by truck, rail or pipeline.  Operations at the Paradis Gas Processing Plant consist of the following: (1) Natural Gas Liquids from off site sources are fractionated into individual hydrocarbon products (ethane, propane, normal butane, iso-butane, and pentane pluses).  (2) The individual hydrocarbon products, with the exception of ethane, are temporarily stored on-site in pressurized vessels prior to shipping.  (3) Ethane is delivered directly into a pipeline.  Other individual hydrocarbon products can be transferred to trucks for shipping at a truck rack, transferred to railcar for shipping at a rail rack, or delivered into pipelines.

The Paradis Gas Processing Plant routinely handles quantities of natural gas, ethane, propane, normal butane and iso-butane, all of which are regulated substances and above the threshold limits listed in EPA?s Risk Management Program rule.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:

Th

e Paradis Gas Processing Plant has implemented all the elements of a Program 3 Risk Management Plan (RMP) and all the elements of OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The plant has also implemented all the elements of Williams Midstream?s System Integrity Plan (SIP), which contains additional environmental, health and safety standards.  Key elements of these programs include:

Employee Participation:  Participation in the development of the Paradis Gas Processing Plant?s process safety and risk management compliance is outlined in the Employee Participation Plan.  Employees and affected contractors have access to information developed as part of the facility?s PSM and accident prevention program.

Process Safety Information: A variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): a systematic examination of the plant to identify possible hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.

Operating Procedures: Paradis Gas Processing Plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial start-up, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) emergency operations, (6) normal shutdown and (7) start-up after turnaround.

Contractors: Paradis Gas Processing Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors, (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) are aware of any hazards in the workplace, (3) Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (4) understand and follow site safety rules, and (5) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR?s): The Paradis Gas Processing Plant uses PSSR?s as a part of the construction pr

ocess.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing modified equipment into service.

Mechanical Integrity: Paradis Gas Processing Plant has well established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, and compressors and emergency shutdown systems in safe operating condition.

Safe Work Practices and Procedures: Examples of safe work practices utilized by the Paradis Gas Processing Plant include methods for controlling plant entry, presence and exit of support personnel, and lockout/Tagout procedures to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, hot work procedures and permits for work with the potential for generating ignition sources in the presence of flammable or combustible material and confined space entry permits and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry is allowed into a permit required confined space.

Training: The plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  The program includes Classroom, OJT and Computer-Based training.  Employees are tested to demonstrate competency.

Management of Change: The Paradis Gas Processing Plant utilizes a Management of Change process.  In this, changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.

Incident Investigation: The Paradis Gas Processing Plant utilizes an Incident Investigation process.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts concerning an incident or near miss and to develop corrective actions to prevent recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.

Compliance Audits: At the Paradis Gas Processing Plant audits are conducted on a regular basis to ensure that the facility is in com

pliance with applicable RMP/PSM/SIP procedure and regulations.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

The Paradis Gas Processing Plant has not experienced an accidental release with RMP on-site or off-site effects during the past 5 years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION:

The Paradis Gas Processing Plant maintains a written emergency response program to protect employees, contractors, public and the environment from hazards associated with accidental releases of regulated substances.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of regulated substances, including the possibility of associated fires or explosions.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, if a release occurs.  Employees? response program changes are administered through the MOC process.  The overall emergency response program for Paradis Gas Processing Plant is coordinated with St. Charles Parish Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes attending periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials and industry representatives.  Paradis Gas Processing Plant has 24-hour communications capability with St. Charles LEPC.  The Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

In response to the most recent Process Hazard Analysis, the Paradis Gas Processing Plant has made several changes to equipment and procedures to reduce either the likelihood and/or the severity of a potential release.  The Paradis Gas Processing Plant will implement any changes identified by future Process Hazard Analysis Revalidations or by future PSM/RMP/SIP audits.
